Fig. 1 X-ray diffraction patterns of 2 wt% Ga impregnated on different structured supports (a) 2Ga/ZIF-8 (b) 2Ga/Hall (c) 2Ga/AlMSU-F (d) 2Ga/CZSM-5 (e) 2Ga/HierMCM-41 (f) 2GGa/GZSM-5 and (g) 2Ga/GZSM-5. Fig 1 Fig. 2 X-ray diffraction patterns of (a) GZSM-5, (b) 2Ga/GZSM-5, (c) 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5, (d) 2Ga0.75Zn/GZSM-5 (e) 2Ga1Zn/GZSM-5, (f) 1Ga1Zn/GZSM-5 and (g) MFI-30. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Nitrogen adsorption isotherm of (a) Commercial ZSM-5 (23), (b) 2Ga/CZSM-5, (c) GZSM-5 and (d) 2Ga/GZSM-5. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Nitrogen adsorption isotherm of (a) 2GGa/GZSM-5, (b) 2Ga/HierMCM-41, (c) 2Ga/Hall, (d) 2Ga/AlMSU-F and (e) 2Ga/ZIF-8. Fig 4 Fig. 5 NH3-TPD of (a) 2Ga/HierMCM-41 (b) 2Ga/Hall, (c) 2Ga/AlMSU-F (d) 2GGa/GZSM-5, (e) 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5, and (f) 2Ga0.5Zn/CZSM-5. Pyridine FT-IR spectra of (g) MFI-30 and (h) 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5. Fig 5 Fig. 6 UV-Vis Diffuse reflectance spectra of (a) GZSM-5, (b) 2Ga/GZSM-5, (c) 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5, (d) 2Ga0.5Zn/CZSM-5, (e) Ga NPs and (f) 2GGa0.5Zn/GZSM-5. Fig 6 Fig. 7 SEM images of (a) 2Ga/GZSM-5, (b) 2Ga/CZSM-5, (c) 2GGa/GZSM-5, and (d) EDS spectrum of 2Ga/GZSM-5. Fig 7 Fig. 8 (a-d) EDS spectrum and elemental mapping of element Si, Al and Ga of 2Ga/GZSM-5, (e-g) HRTEM images of 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 (500 nm, 200 nm and 10 nm), (h) 2Ga0.5Zn/HierMCM-41, (i) 2Ga0.5Zn/Hall and (j) 2Ga0.5Zn/Al-MSU-F at 100 nm. Interdisciplinary Research Center for Refining and Advanced Chemicals King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals Dhahran 31261 Saudi Arabia This study explores the performance of bimetal Ga-Zn impregnated on green ZSM-5 and commercial ZSM-5 to convert liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) to aromatics. Initially, the activity of Ga-impregnated GZSM-5 (2Ga/GZSM-5) was evaluated and compared with various structured catalysts, halloysite clay nanotubes (2Ga/Hall), hierarchical MCM-41 (2Ga/HierMCM-41), mesocellular aluminosilicate foam (2Ga/AlMSU-F), and zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (2Ga/ZIF-8). The experiments were conducted using an LPG feed at a flow rate of 10 mL/min and 550 °C. Subsequently, the effect of Zn co-impregnation on 2Ga/GZSM-5, was investigated. Finally, a sustainable catalyst derived from green Ga-Zn metal nanoparticles synthesized from Tribulus leaves on GZSM-5 (2GGa0.5Zn/GZSM-5) was studied. The results revealed that 2Ga/GZSM-5 exhibited the highest aromatics yield of 72.64 % with a BTEX selectivity of 61.10 %. Among the bimetallic catalysts, 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 achieved the highest aromatics yield of 76.00 % with a BTEX selectivity of 44.38 %. This study highlights the potential of sustainable green metal nanoparticles combined with ZSM-5 for efficient LPG-to-aromatics conversion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Green catalysts LPG Aromatics bimetallic catalysts halloysite clay Tribulus leaves MCM-41 mesocellular foam Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Aromatic hydrocarbons such as benzene, toluene and xylene generally referred as BTX has been used widely in chemical and petrochemical industries. The global demands for such hydrocarbons rise continuously in Asia-Pacific (China, India), US and Europe and was expected to increase up to 169 million tons by 2025 with the growth rate of about 40 % [1]. In order to meet the demand, several new feedstocks are being explored in addition to traditional process such as UOP/BP cyclar process and naptha catalytic reforming [2]. Dehydroaromatization is one of the process of converting methane into valuable BTX. This single direct step process is reported to be advantageous in terms of energy efficient process with high aromatics selectivity. However, such process exhibits some of the drawbacks such as lower conversion rate due to high thermodynamic stability of reactant (methane), coke deposition and particle aggregation. Several authors have investigated the effect of co-feed such as alkenes, alkanes and H2/CO2 to improve the activation of methane [3]. The natural gas as co-feed shown to improve the catalytic activity of 3 wt%Ga/ZSM-5 catalyst life by increasing the BTX yield, reducing the pore plugging and catalytic deactivation [2]. The production of BTX was reported through catalytic hydrocracking and hydrotreating of heavy aromatics (C10 +) using dual catalyst system of Mo2C/γ-Al2O3 and composite of Beta/ZSM-5. Mo2C/γ-Al2O3 catalyst promoted mono aromatic products, while combinational Beta/ZSM-5 catalyst improved the yield of BTX and reduced the alkylbenzenes through dealkylation along with heavier aromatics. Metals such as Nickel molybdenum impregnation over Beta/ZSM-5 resulted in high BTX (47.7 %) BTX+C9 aromatics yield (61.1 wt%). Further, the mechanistic route revealed the transalkylation among benzene, toluene and tetramethylbenzenes improved the formation of BTX [4]. Catalytic hydrocracking of biomass derived tar to BTX using metal modified ZSM-5 was reported as a promising route in ambient pressure condition. 5 wt% metal (Zr, Nb, Sn, Ga, Ni, Ni-Mo), 20 wt% W and phosphotungstic acid loading on ZSM-5 was loaded using wet impregnation technique. The activity of ZSM-5 without metal loading exhibited highest BTX selectivity (45.6 %) with high conversion of tetralin (94.6 %) after 4 h. At the long run, 5 %Zr impregnated ZSM-5 showed a selectivity of 24.2 % after 25 h [5]. Selective aromatization of light olefin (1-hexene) to BTX using silicalite-1 coated ZSM-5 was reported to be promising approach. Passivation of the external acid sites of ZSM-5 (core) by silicalite (shell) was reported to improve the selectivity of BTX (37.15 %) and para xylene (58.65 %) with reduced coke deactivation and increased catalyst life [6]. The grafting of organometallic complex at the external silanol groups of ZSM-5 (TiNp4 grafted ZSM-5) activated the C-H bond of alkane, while the acidity property of zeolite facilitated oligomerization, cyclization, and aromatization leading to BTX selectivity of 55 % [7]. The coaromatization of n-hexane and methanol over Ga, Zn impregnated ZSM-5 has been shown to increase the BTX yield (70 %). Presence of bimetals was reported to tune the active sites GaO+/ Zn(OH)+ and improve the dehydroaromatization property leading to increased aromatic yield [8]. The presence of Ga+ facilitates dehydrogenation leading to olefins (oxidative addition), while the acid sites of zeolite favors oligomerization, cyclization and aromatization [9]. It has been observed that presence of 1 %Zn in propane aromatization also facilitates dehydrogenation, cyclization and aromatization [10]. Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG), primarily composed of propane and butane, is a versatile and widely used fuel known for its clean-burning properties and high calorific value. Traditionally utilized in residential, industrial, and automotive applications, LPG has recently gained significant attention as a potential feedstock for producing high-value chemicals, particularly aromatics such as benzene, toluene, and xylenes (BTX) [11]. The process of converting LPG to aromatics involves several steps, typically encompassing dehydrogenation, aromatization, and product separation. Dehydrogenation is the critical initial step, where propane and butane are transformed into olefins, which are then further converted into aromatic compounds through catalytic aromatization. This transformation leverages advanced catalysts and reactor technologies to maximize yield and selectivity while minimizing energy consumption and environmental impact. The demand for sustainable, environmentally friendly chemical processes and synthesis cost has led to the development of green catalysts, which reduce the environmental impact on industrial scale [12]. Among various materials, clay mineral has emerged as a promising precursor for green catalyst synthesis. Green synthesis of nano ZSM-5 single crystals has been reported using natural clay resource. For uniform crystallinity, this technique involves control of nucleation and growth factor by aging the sample and demonstrated better activity than commercial ZSM-5 in methanol to propylene conversion [13]. Green preparation of template free ZSM-5 using industrial waste silica fume showed generation of hierarchical pore formation with oval shaped particles (2.0 μm) active for co-cracking to produce selective BTEX (88.5 %) [14]. Natural clay (kaolin) has been used as the precursor for silica and aluminium for the preparation of submicron size ZSM-5 with high textural meso characteristics (surface area = 406 m2/g) in the form of nano aggregated ZSM-5 [15]. In our recent study, we reported the green route synthesis of ZSM-5 using kaolin (bolus alpha) and clay nanotube (halloysite) as precursors for aluminosilicate. The hydrothermally synthesized ZSM-5 exhibited hierarchical characteristics availing both mesopore (45 m2/g)/micropore surface area (123 m2/g) with total acidity of 0.209 mmol/g. In addition, the ZSM-5 derived from clay showed a high intense tetrahedral aluminium species incorporated into the framework than conventional ZSM-5, which was reflected in steam catalytic cracking activity of AXL crude oil [16]. This paper explores the activity of sustainable green ZSM-5 on the catalytic conversion of LPG to valuable aromatics. Three combinational Ga impregnated catalyst formulations based on conventional ZSM-5 (Ga/CZSM-5), green ZSM-5 (Ga/GZSM-5) and green Ga metal/green ZSM-5 (GGa/GZSM-5) were studied for LPG conversion to high BTX selectivity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Mixture of propane (25 Vol.%) and butane (25 Vol.%) in nitrogen (50 Vol.%) used as LPG feed was purchased from Abdullah Hashim gas company in Saudi Arabia. The commercial ZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 ratios 23) with surface area of 425 m2/g identified as CBV 2314 was obtained from Zeolyst International, Kansas City, USA. Halloysite, a nanoclay (Al2Si2O5(OH)4.2H2O) with surface area of 64 m2/g, diameter (30-70 nm) × length (1-3 μm), Bolus alpha (Al2Si2O5(OH)4) and mesocellular aluminosilicate foam (AlMSU-F) with window cell of about 15 nm and surface area of 562 m2/g were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich, Darmstadt, Germany. ZIF-8 (Basolite Z1200) with particle size of 4.9 μm and surface area of about 1300-1800 m2/g was obtained from BASF, Sigma Aldrich, Darmstadt, Germany. 2.2 Synthesis of Green ZSM-5 (GZSM-5) Firstly, 5 g of halloysite was transformed to metakaolin through calcination at 700 °C for 2 h (heating rate of 5 °C/min). Thereafter, 2 g of metakaolin powder was mixed in 2.5 M NaOH solution (10 ml) and stirred for 1 h. Followingly, 23 g of silica source (Ludox AS-40) was dispersed in alkaline solution and stirred for 1 h. Then zeolite seed solution (0.18 g ZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 80)/10 ml) was added and then the mixture was stirred and aged for 12 h. The solution was hydrothermally treated at 175 °C for 72 h. Finally, the solution mixture was filtered through vacuum filteration, washed, dried and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h (5 °C/min). 2.3 Synthesis of Ga and Ga-Zn nanoparticles using leaves The gallium and zinc nanoparticles were synthesized using Tribulus leaves extract. Firstly, 5 g of leaves were taken and added in 100 ml of distilled water and heated at 90 °C for 4 h, then then filtered. Then 50 ml of gallium nitrate or gallium nitrate-zinc nitrate was added and mixed for 1 h at 45 °C and then completely dried. 2.4 Impregnation of Ga or Ga-Zn on different support materials For 2 wt% loading, 0.073 g of gallium nitrate was added in 60 ml of distilled water and stirred for dissolution. After that, 1 g of GZSM-5 was added and stirred for 6 h. Then the solution mixture was dried at 100 °C and then calcined at 550 °C for 3 h at 5 °C/min. For comparative study, the different structured support such as halloysite, hierarchical Mobil Composition of Matter No. 41 (MCM-41), mesocellular aluminosilicate foam (AlMSU-F) and zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 were used instead of GZSM-5 and similar procedure was repeated. For bimetal impregnation, 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5; 0.073 g of gallium nitrate was taken and dissolved in 60 ml of distilled water and stirred for dissolution. Then 0.017 g of zinc acetate dihydrate was added and stirred for 10 min. The catalyst support GZSM-5 was added and stirred for 6 h. Followingly, the mixture was filtered, dried and calcined at 550 °C for 3 h at 5 °C/min (Scheme 1 ). Uniform gallium loading (2 wt%) was maintained across all samples, while the support structure was varied, including hierarchical MCM-41, halloysite, mesocellular aluminosilicate foam. The developed catalysts are abbreviated in the format presented in Table 1 . 2.5 Catalyst characterization Mobil-type five (MFI) phase of green zeolite, Ga, Ga-Zn modified GZSM-5, commercial ZSM-5 and mesoporous supports was studied by powder X-ray diffraction analysis (Miniflex II, Rigaku, Japan). The scan range for samples were 5-60° (1°/min speed) by Cu Kα X-ray source, λ = 1.5405 Å along with energy of 30 kV and 15 mA. The surface and pore architecture of synthesized samples were analyzed by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Micromeritics, ASAP 2020, USA). The Ga, Ga-Zn distribution, morphology of GZSM-5 and HierMCM-41 was analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analysis (JSM-6610LV, JEOL) and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEM2100F from JEOL Ltd, Tokyo, Japan). The Ammonium temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments was performed to determine the acidity of catalyst samples using BELCAT reactor system (Japan). The samples underwent initial heating to 500 °C for 1 h while being exposed to a flow of 50 ml/min of helium, followed by cooling to room temperature. After that, a mixture of 5 % ammonia in helium was introduced at 100 °C for 30 minutes, and then the samples were heated to 120 °C under helium (50 ml/min) to eliminate loosely bonded ammonia. Subsequently, the samples were cooled to room temperature, then heated to 600 °C under a flow of 25 ml/min of helium. The amount of released ammonia was measured using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Temperature programmed reduction using hydrogen (H2-TPR) was performed using hydrogen/nitrogen mixture (5 vol.%) at heating rate of 10 °C/min between 100-900 °C. The reduction potential of various samples was monitored with consumption of hydrogen using thermal conductivity detector of BELCAT reactor. The coke content of the spent catalyst was measured using Horiba Carbon-Sulfur Analyzer (EMIA-220 V). Prior to the analysis, the temperature increased to 1200 °C. A calculated amount of tungsten (10-20 mg) was added as promoter to combust the spent catalyst. Thereafter, the CO2 gas formed was measured using infrared analyzer. The amounts of metals were quantified using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) Horiba ULTIMA 2 instrument (Table S1). 2.6 Catalyst testing A laboratory-scale fixed-bed reactor system was used to carry out the aromatization of LPG feed (25 % propane+25 % butane+50 % N2 mixture). The details of reactor setup are given in our previous work [17] (Scheme 2 ). In a typical experiment 1.0 ml of catalyst particles (sieved between 500–1000 µm) were placed in the middle of the SS reactor tube, along with the packing of inert silicon carbide particles above and below the catalyst bed. The catalyst was activated at 550 °C under a nitrogen flow of 10 ml/min for one hour. Following activation, the reactor was supplied with LPG feed. The aromatization reaction was performed at 550 °C, with a Gas Hourly Space Velocity (GHSV) of 1600 h−1 and Time on Stream (TOS) of 5 h. The characterization of products was performed using an online GC equipped with TCD and FID detectors. The detailed hydrocarbon analysis was conducted using Agilent's DHA software. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 X-ray diffraction (XRD) The effect of different structured catalysts including metal organic framework (ZIF-8), aluminosilicate clay halloysite, mesocellular aluminosilicate foam, commercial ZSM-5, hierarchical MCM-41 and green ZSM-5 were studied in LPG aromatization to investigate the influence of pore architecture on product distribution. The effect of gallium dispersion across these structures was also evaluated to understand its role in enhancing aromatics yield. The phase transformation of Ga impregnated on different structured nanocarriers such as ZIF-8, green ZSM-5, halloysite nanotube, hierarchical MCM-41, ZIF-8, mesocellular foam, and green Ga loaded on green ZSM-5 was shown in Fig. 1 . Parent ZIF-8 showed several characteristics sharp peaks confirming the crystallinity and phase purity of sodalite topology. Similarly, the XRD pattern of 2Ga/ZIF-8 exhibited several such diffractions characteristics of crystalline structure of sodalite. However, the most intense peak corresponding to (011) reflection plane at 7.3° decreases (∼35 %) with Ga impregnation (Fig. 1a). The positions of peaks also slightly vary indicating a modification in the framework structure and size reduction in the crystal size with impregnation (Figure S1a and b). Halloysite without Ga modification showed a well resolved peaks corresponding to the clay crystalline structure, while the observed peak broadening was ascribed due to the tubular morphology. The most prominent peak appears at 20° followed by secondary peaks at 11.8°, 24°, 26° and 34-60°. Ga impregnated halloysite (2Ga/Hall) showed an alteration in the crystalline peaks with decreased intensity suggesting Ga interaction with the clays interlayers possibly intercalation between the layers (Fig. 1b) [18]. Compared to parent halloysite, a disruption in the regular stacking of layers is observed leading to reduction in crystallinity and alteration of diffraction patterns (Figure S1c and d). Mesocellular aluminosilicate exhibits an amorphous peak at 2 theta range of 23° indicating short range order of Si-O-Si and Al-O-Si linkages within foam type framework. Ga impregnated mesocellular foam (2Ga/AlMSU-F) showed a less intense broad peak with peak maxima at about 23°due to their amorphous framework nature typical to the mesocellular foam (Fig. 1c). The absence of gallium peaks indicate that gallium is in highly dispersed form (Figure S1e and f). Ga impregnated on commercial ZSM-5(23) (2Ga/CZSM-5) showed a distinct high intensity crystalline sharp peaks, characteristic of MFI structure (Fig. 1d). There is no significant change was noticed between the diffraction pattern of parent MFI (23) and 2Ga/CZSM-5. For instance, the main peaks at 23°, 23.7° and 24.2° indicates the preservation of structure after deposition of Ga metal ions at the micropore structure (Figure S1g and h). 2Ga/HierMCM-41, 2Ga/GZSM-5 and 2GGa/ZSM-5 showed a typical diffraction patterns reflecting MFI structure similar to commercial ZSM-5 but the presence of hierarchy tends to broaden the peaks indicating the presence of amorphous characteristics along with zeolitic properties (Fig. 1e-g). After gallium impregnation on HierMCM-41, a reduction in high-angle XRD peak intensity was observed, indicating a partial disruption or distortion of the mesoporous framework (Figure S1i and j). Compared to MFI-30, the intensity of GZSM-5 peak at 23° decreases to about 20 %, which indicates the rearrangement of MFI phase of GZSM-5 after Ga impregnation. Specifically, the formation of ZSM-5 zeolite using metakaolin as a precursor involves several chemical and hydrothermal steps. The thermal treatment of halloysite at 700 °C within 0.5 – 2 h was sufficient to form metakaolin, an amorphous and highly reactive aluminosilicate (Figure S2). This metakaolin, serves as the aluminum and silicon source in the synthesis. In the second step, metakaolin is mixed with silica source (Ludox AS-40), zeolitic seed solution, water, and NaOH as a mineralizing agent. This forms a homogeneous gel containing reactive aluminosilicate species. During hydrothermal crystallization (third step), the gel is aged and then heated hydrothermally at 175 °C for 72 h. During this period, depolymerization of metakaolin into soluble alumino- and silico-species occurs leading to reorganization of these species into secondary building units. Further, nucleation and growth of the GZSM-5 crystal structure was directed by seeds of zeolitic species that could contribute to the observed MFI phase of GZSM-5. However, after gallium impregnation on GZSM-5, the XRD peak intensity increased, indicating enhanced crystallinity or improved structural ordering of the zeolite framework, possibly due to stabilization effects from gallium species (Figure S1k-m). For all catalysts, the absence of bulk Ga2O3 phase confirms the distribution of Ga species inside the pore architecture of each sample [19]. Further the reduced peak intensity of Ga showed the presence of gallium as nanosized oxide well below the detection limit of XRD [20]. Fig. 2 (a-g) shows the X-ray diffraction pattern of GZSM-5, 2Ga/GZSM-5, 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5, 2Ga0.75Zn/GZSM-5, 2Ga1.0Zn/GZSM-5, 1Ga1Zn/GZSM-5, and MFI-30, respectively. GZSM-5 and loaded GZSM-5 exhibits well indexed peaks corresponding to the pure MFI phase matching well with the commercial MFI-30. However, the XRD diffraction peaks of pure GZSM-5 are broader and less intense compared to those of crystalline ZSM-5 (MFI-30), indicating a smaller crystallite size and reduced long-range order (Fig. 2a). This broadening and intensity reduction reflect the nanocrystalline nature of the material. Despite lower intensity, characteristic MFI-type peaks confirm the retention of ZSM-5 framework structure. In all the samples, addition the Ga and Zn had little influence on the MFI structure. For instance, all the samples showed a broad but well-defined XRD peaks corresponding to the ZSM-5 structure. A minor shift in the peak maxima occurs due to introduction of bimetals, indicating the introduction into the ZSM-5 lattice leading to subtle lattice distortions (Fig. 2b-f). It has also been shown that such a change in the peak intensity signals the incorporation of extra-framework Ga-Zn species and results in slight amorphization [20]. In similar stance to Ga, the presence of ZnO species were not visible for the samples as the loading is well below 2 wt% [21]. The XRD diffraction peaks of crystalline MFI-30 are sharp and intense, indicating high crystallinity and well-ordered structure. These peaks are significantly more defined than those of nanoZSM-5, reflecting its larger crystal size and long-range order (Fig. 2g). 3.1.3 Textural characterization using nitrogen adsorption isotherm The surface and pore architecture of CZSM-5, 2Ga/CZSM-5, GZSM-5 and 2Ga/GZSM-5 were analyzed using nitrogen adsorption technique (Fig. 3 a-d). The textural characteristics are presented in Table 2 . Pure commercial CZSM-5 sample showed a typical I isotherm characteristics of micropore based material (Fig. 3a). In the case of gallium impregnated on commercial ZSM-5 based catalyst, 2Ga/CZSM-5 exhibited a similar texture even after impregnation indicating the presence of micropores in major proportion (Fig. 3b). In case of pure GZSM-5, the sample exhibited an intermediate type III isotherm (H3 hysteresis) adsorption-desorption isotherm at relative pressure range P/P0 of 0.45-1.0 indicating the presence of hierarchical types of pores (Fig. 3c). 2Ga/GZSM-5 exhibited a steep rise in the hysteresis at higher relative pressures (P/P0 ˃ 0.75) indicating a characteristic change in the pore architectures with gallium impregnation (Fig. 3d). The t-plot using Harkins and Jura equation differentiated the presence of micropore and mesoporous surface area. For instance, GZSM-5 without Ga modification showed the surface area of 257 m2/g contributed mostly by micropore surface of 161 m2/g and external mesoporous surface area of 96 m2/g. After Ga impregnation, the textural characteristics of Ga/GZSM-5 increased compared to parent GZSM-5. The surface area increases to 316 m2/g with an estimated ∼20 % and ∼18 % increase in the micropore and mesoporous surface area. The elevation in the pore volume from 0.17 cm3/g to 0.28 cm3/g (40 % increase) was observed along with pore size diameter from 2.7 nm to 3.5 nm (23 % increase) (Table 2). Such an increase clearly indicates the contribution from Ga deposition at the pore walls rather than encapsulation inside the pores of GZSM-5. . The textural properties of the green Ga-deposited GZSM-5 catalyst (2GGa/GZSM-5) exhibited a slight increase in surface area, reaching 276 m²/g compared to the parent GZSM-5 surface area of 257 m²/g. Notably, the micropore surface area increased to 190 m²/g from 161 m²/g. Additionally, the total pore volume rose from 0.17 cm³/g to 0.27 cm³/g, while the average pore size expanded from 2.70 nm to 3.90 nm (Fig. 4 a).The N2 sorption isotherm of Ga/HierMCM-41 was of type-IV pattern with capillary inflection at P/P0 = 0.4-0.5 indicating predominant mesoporous characteristics (213 m2/g) due to the mesoporous templated (cetyltrimethylammonium bromide) synthesis of hierarchical MCM-41 (Fig. 4b). Parent hierarchical MCM-41 showed a high surface area of 846 m2/g, while after Ga impregnation, the surface area reduced to 270 m2/g. In a similar stance, the pore volume reduces from 0.58 cm3/g to 0.27 cm3/g, while an increase in pore diameter was observed from 2.7 nm to 4 nm, respectively. The result shows that Ga impregnation over hierarchical MCM-41 favors encapsulation inside the large hexagonal pores leading to the reduction in the surface area and pore volume [22]. 2Ga/Hall with nanotube morphology exhibited a type IV isotherm pattern (H3 hysteresis) with a lower surface area of 26 m2/g with a reduction of 66 % from 77 m2/g after Ga impregnation. The pore volume showed a systematic reduction from 0.34 cm3/g to 0.27 cm3/g. The gradual textural reduction of halloysite nanotube also indicated Ga deposition at the external wall with increase pore diameter from 17.7 nm to 41 nm (Fig. 4c). The parent MSU-F exhibited a type H1 hysteresis isotherm, characteristic of mesoporous materials with uniform pore structures, and possessed a high surface area of 540 m²/g, a pore volume of 2.3 cm³/g, and an average pore diameter of 16.9 nm. Upon impregnation of Ga, the 2Ga/AlMSU-F sample demonstrated significant changes, indicating gallium deposition within the large-window pores. This modification resulted in a substantial reduction in surface area (300 m²/g, a 44 % decrease), pore volume (0.27 cm³/g, an 88 % decrease), and average pore diameter (3.6 nm, a 79 % decrease), respectively (Fig. 4d). Ga/ZIF-8 showed a characteristics microporous texture with type I isotherm pattern with surface area of 896 m2/g (Fig. 4e). The t-plot showed the high content of microporous character (828 m2/g) with a few mesoporous surface area of 67 m2/g. The characteristics of parent ZIF-8 as shown inside the bracket showed that the presence of large surface area can easily accommodate the impregnation of Ga. 3.1.4 NH3-TPD and Pyridine FT-IR analysis The acidity of 2Ga/HierMCM-41, 2Ga/Hall, 2Ga/AlMSU-F, 2GGa/GZSM-5, 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 and 2Ga0.5Zn/CZSM-5 was analyzed using NH3-TPD analysis (Fig. 5 a-f and Table 3 ). The Ga impregnated samples showed different desorption peaks between 100 -350 °C corresponding to the weak and medium acid sites and between 350 – 600 °C corresponding to the strong acid sites, respectively. Ga and Zn impregnated over commercial ZSM-5 exhibited a high density of acid strength ascribed to weak acid sites (0.555 mmol/g), and strong acid sites (0.671 mmolg). The total acidity of 1.226 mmol/g remains the highest among all the samples. 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 exhibited a weak-medium acid site of 0.532 mmol/g and strong acid sites of 0.245 mmol/g. The sample showed the second highest total acidity of 0.777 mmol/g. The green plant derived Ga impregnation on green ZSM-5 showed a less weak acid sites of 0.291 mmol/g, while presence of strong acid sites (0.329 mmol/g) was observed more than weak acid sites leading to total acid sites of 0.620 mmol/g. This result shows the Ga impregnation on green ZSM-5 exhibits intermediate acidity balancing between the weak and strong acid sites compared to commercial MFI-30 (Figure not shown). However, the impregnation of Ga on large pore catalyst such as 2Ga/AlMSU-F and 2Ga/HierMCM-41showed formation of higher proportion of weak acid strength than strong acid sites with total acidity lesser than ZSM-5 based catalyst. 2Ga/Hall showed the lowest acidity with weak acid sites of 0.085 mmol/g and strong acid sites of 0.173 mmol/g with total acidity of 0.258 mmol/g. The order of samples is 2Ga0.5Zn/CZSM-5 > 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 > 2GGa/GZSM-5 > 2Ga/AlMSU-F > 2Ga/HierMCM-41 > 2Ga/Hall. The intermediate weak-medium and strong acid sites of GZSM-5 was observed in comparison with commercial ZSM-5, and this may be correlated with the external disposition of the Ga metal across the pore surface as observed in the BET surface area results. Yakerson et al. [23] has stated that Ga3+ at the external surface of catalyst contribute to Lewis acid site. However, co-impregnation of zinc (Zn2+ ions) was reported to accelerate the proton exchange of hydroxyl groups and enhances the strong Lewis acid sites. To investigate the amount of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, pyridine-adsorbed FTIR spectroscopy was performed on selected samples (a) MFI-30 and (b) 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 (Fig. 5g and h). The characteristic absorption bands corresponding to Brønsted acid sites (∼1540 cm⁻¹) and Lewis acid sites (∼1450 cm⁻¹) were analyzed to compare their relative acid site concentrations. 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 exhibits Lewis acid sites at 0.37 mmol/g and Brønsted acid sites at 0.544 mmol/g, resulting in a total acidity of 0.914 mmol/g. In comparison, MFI-30 contains 0.24 mmol/g of Lewis acid sites and 1.6 mmol/g of Brønsted acid sites, yielding a total acidity of 1.84 mmol/g. While MFI-30 possesses a higher concentration of Brønsted acid sites, reflected by a low Lewis-to-Brønsted acid site (L/B) ratio of 0.15, 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 exhibits a significantly higher L/B ratio of 0.638, indicating an increased proportion of Lewis acid sites. 3.1.5 UV-Visible Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-Vis DRS) The coordination state of Al in GZSM-5, commercial ZSM-5 and influence of Ga, Zn over GZSM-5 was analyzed using solid state diffuse reflectance spectroscopy in absorption mode. Fig. 6 (a-f) shows the diffuse reflectance spectra of GZSM-5, 2Ga/GZSM-5, 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5, 2Ga0.5Zn/CZSM-5, Ga NPs and 2GGa0.5Zn/GZSM-5. GZSM-5 has only two distinct peaks at about 210 nm and 250 nm extending up to 300 nm (Fig. 6a). This indicates that GZSM-5 consists of a high number of incorporated Al3+ in tetrahedral state signaling framework Al species ascribed to charge transfer band. The spectrum of 2Ga/GZSM-5 showed a similar absorption band to that of GZSM-5 but with a distinct additional shoulder band characteristics of Ga appear at about 285 nm (Fig. 6b). This characteristics indicate the successful nanocomposite formation after Ga impregnation on GZSM-5. The addition of Zn to Ga/GZSM-5 showed no other distinct band of Zn but rather appeared similar absorption to that of 2Ga/GZSM-5 (Fig. 6c). The 2Ga0.5 Zn impregnation on commercial ZSM-5 showed high absorption of bands corresponding to framework and extra-framework Al species, while the band correspond to Ga (at about 285 nm) was reduced compared to GZSM-5 (Fig. 6d). This shows that commercial ZSM-5 has a greater number of isolated/paired Al-O-Si species [24]. In the raw form, green Ga NPs prepared using Tribulus leaves have a distinct broad band with peak maxima at about 350 nm (Fig. 6e). The presence of plant composite formation extends the Ga ion absorption in visible light up to 450 nm. It has been observed that effective composite formation between Ga and carbon nitride shifted the peak absorption of Ga towards visible region of about 430 nm [25]. In this study, the presence of plant extract and composite formation of GZSM-5 tends to exert similar effect to that of carbon nitride support. 2Ga0.5Zn/CZSM-5 showed a strong peak at about 254 nm indicating a high framework incorporated Al species, while the lower Ga ion peak height shows a stronger interaction with Ga clusters than GZSM-5 [26,27]. On contrary, the presence of broad Ga clusters absorption band was high over GZSM-5 indicating the presence of labile Ga clusters interacting mildly with the framework of MFI. In case of green Ga and Zn impregnation on green ZSM-5, the sample exhibited a Ga absorption band shifting towards lower wavelength at about 270 nm indicating formation of bulk like clusters (Fig. 6f) [28]. Furthermore, in order to analyze the reduction properties, H2-TPR analysis was performed for selected samples 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5, 2Ga0.5Zn/CZSM-5, 2Ga0.75Zn/GZSM-5 and 2Ga/AlMSU-F (Figure S3). 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 showed two peaks with peak maxima at about 528 °C accompanied by a shoulder peak at about 605 °C. It has been reported that the peak at about 600 °C and below represents the reduction from the dispersed GaO+ or Ga2O3 (microparticles) interacting with the GZSM-5 support [29]. It has been further stated that such as lower reduction peak indicates well dispersion gallium species and can be correlated with the acidic property of the catalyst. When the Zn content increases to 0.75 wt% as in 2Ga0.75Zn/GZSM-5, the dispersion of gallium ion seems to be affected leading to the increase in the reduction temperature from 528 °C to about 590 °C. The absence of peak at about 900 °C indicates the absence of loosely bound bulk Ga2O3 particles. In case of commercial ZSM-5 support, a slightly increase in the reduction temperature was observed at about 540 °C. Large surface foam type support AlMSU-F shows the high reduction temperature at about 658 °C indicating the variable influence of support textural characteristics on gallium dispersion. 3.1.6 Scanning electron microscope (SEM) Fig. 7 (a-c) shows the morphological images of 2Ga/GZSM-5, 2Ga/CZSM-5 and 2GGa/GZSM-5 at similar magnification using SEM analysis. The EDS spectrum of 2Ga/GZSM-5 was shown in Fig. 7d. The samples showed a unique morphologies based on the green and commercial based ZSM-5. 2Ga/CZSM-5 sample based on green ZSM-5 showed a well-defined spherical morphology in agglomerated cluster form (Fig. 7a). 2Ga/CZSM-5 based on commercial ZSM-5 catalyst showed a variable morphology with chunk like larger crystallites without uniform morphology. The sample exhibited an irregulated crystals in aggregation form at micron size level (Fig. 7b). 2GGa/GZSM-5 based on green gallium nanoparticles impregnated on green ZSM-5 showed a larger spherical morphology slightly varying to the morphology of 2Ga/GZSM-5 (Fig. 7c). The atomic percentage of Ga on GZSM-5 has further validated the purity and constituent of Ga, Al and Si elements (Fig. 7d). The Si, Al and Ga elemental distributions were mapped using EDX mapping (Fig. 8 a-d). The dispersion of Ga is well distributed along with Si and Al species. The finding shows that densification or agglomeration of active sites are not observed with kaolin to metakaolin transformation, followed by ZSM-5 synthesis. Fig. 8(e-g) shows the HRTEM images of 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 (500 nm and 10 nm) and 2Ga0.5Zn/HierMCM-41 at 100 nm. The images of 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 clearly show the cubic shaped crystals without any distinct separated or agglomerated Ga phase (Fig. 8e-g). In the case of hierarchical MCM-41 support, a clear hierarchical pore channels including mesopores interrupted by the nano zeolitic clusters are seen running along the perpendicular axis, while halloysite nanotubes and mesocellular foam showed distinct tube and foam types of porous characteristic structure (Fig. 8h-j). In the impregnated structured catalyst, the absence of distinct Ga and Zn species indicates an amorphous form uniformly distributed on the surface of support (Fig. 8h-j). 3.2 LPG to Aromatics 3.2.1 Catalytic activity of Ga impregnated GZSM-5 The bifunctional catalyst consisting of gallium species (extra-framework) along the proximity of acid sites plays a critical role in facilitating the conversion of alkanes to aromatics [30]. To study the effect of different shaped catalysts on the nature of Ga dispersion, four different support with different textural pore architectures were chosen and studied the aromatization effect. Table 4 shows the effect of Ga impregnated different structured catalysts on product distributions for conversion of LPG at 550 °C and atmospheric pressure. The LPG feed consists mainly of C3 and C4 mixture. MFI-30 was tested as standard commercial catalyst and compared the activity of 2Ga/Halloysite, 2Ga/GZSM-5, 2GGa/GZSM-5 and 2Ga/AlMSU-F. The catalytic performance was studied by comparing the aromatic yield, selectivity of BTEX, C9+, benzene to toluene ratio (B/T ratio), and light hydrocarbons. As presented in Table 4, the LPG conversion over MFI-30 showed 82.11 % of C3 conversion and 100 % conversion of C4. The aromatic yield of 48.54 % was observed with BTEX selectivity of 46.09 %, C9+ selectivity of 2.45 % and light hydrocarbons of 43.01 %. The Ga impregnated halloysite (2Ga/Hall) with very low surface area but with high nanotube diameter (30-70 nm) and length (1-3 μm) exhibited a very low alkane (C3 & C4) conversion of 0.43 % and 4.69 % respectively. The catalyst also showed no BTEX formation, while a lower selectivity to light hydrocarbons (2.83 %) were observed. The observed lower performance could be mainly attributed to the morphological features and distribution nature of active sites in the Hall nanotube. The silicon oxide layer is present at the outer surface of Hall, while active aluminium oxide is present at the inner side of the nanotube. The external deposition of Ga remains isolated and without the assistance of Bronsted acid sites results in lower aromatics selectivity. The narrow feature of nanotube tends to reduce the activity and aromatics formation. Ga/MSU-F composed of large surface area (300 m2/g) and pore window size of 3.6 nm was studied for conversion of LPG. Similar to halloysite nanotubes, the presence of foam type of catalyst showed lowest (C3 & C4) conversion of 0.51 % and 3.52 % with formation of fewer light hydrocarbons (2.21 %). This clearly shows the requirement of acid site accessibility (Ga and Al cohabitation) of alkane feed to active site of catalyst. Though the foam type provides enhanced accessibility to active sites unlike nanotube, the presence of large window size is also found to be inactive for aromatization activity. The tube and large pore foam type catalyst are not suitable for LPG conversion. Similarly, the Ga loaded ZIF-8, Ga impregnated HierarM41 showed no activity (0 % conversion of LPG). However, the green combinational catalyst Ga/GZSM-5 showed highest (C3 & C4) conversion of 93.34 % and 100 %. Impressively, the aromatic yield was highest of 72.64 % with BTEX selectivity of 61.10 % (Fig. 9 a). The C9+ selectivity also increased to 11.53 %, while the light hydrocarbons selectivity decreases to 22.55 % compared to MFI catalyst (43.01 %). Green Ga derived from Tribulus plant impregnated on GZSM-5 (2GGa/GZSM-5) showed a unique activity with less C3 conversion of 0.16 % and high C4 conversion of 94.88 % with aromatic yield of 30.32 % (Fig. 9b). The aromatics consist of BTEX without the formation of C9+. Like Ga/GZSM-5, the catalyst showed about 22.39 % of light hydrocarbons. This shows that green based Ga and ZSM-5 formulations possess the expected BTEX selectivity and desired surface acidity to transform the LPG to aromatics. 3.2.2 Effect of different weight percentage Ga-Zn on GZSM-5 The effect of Ga-Zn combination on GZSM-5 on the alkane conversion, aromatics yield and BTEX selectivity is presented in Table 5 . In case of 0.5 wt% co-impregnation of Zn along with 2 wt% Ga on GZSM-5 (2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5), the conversion of C3 and C4 remains almost the same with 93.14 % and 100 %, while the total aromatic yield increased to 76 %. Notably, the BTX selectivity reduced to 44.38 %, while C9+ selectivity increased to 31.62 %. It has been reported that such aromatization activity of Zn species is mostly associated with the Lewis acid sites of medium strength acid sites assisting dehydrogenation [31]. The B/T ratio reduces from 0.93 to 0.73 along with light hydrocarbons to 15.75 %, respectively. The addition of 0.75 wt% Zn to 2 wt% Ga, resulted in a lower C3 conversion to 35.19 %, while C4 conversion slightly reduces to 98.91 %. The catalyst showed a lower aromatic selectivity in terms of aromatics yield (32.66 %) and BTX (29.89 %) selectivity. The C9+ selectivity reduced significantly to 2.76 %, while the B/T remains highest to 1.15. Further increasing the Zn content to 1.00 wt. %, showed some improvement but remains lesser than 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 catalyst. In case of equal proportion of Ga and Zn loading on GZSM-5 (1Ga1Zn/GZSM-5), the C3 conversion reduced to 48.58 %, while the C4 conversion remained at 99.64 %. The aromatic yield and BTX selectivity were lower and remained at 56.60 % and 52.93 %, respectively. The co-impregnation study indicates that the addition of 0.5 wt.% Zn improves the aromatics yield and C9+ selectivity but at the cost of BTX selectivity. The conversion of light alkane to aromatics can be catalyzed using ZSM-5 but diffusion limitation leads to cracking products and coke formation. The presence of transition metals such as Ga and Zn tends to facilitate the dehydrogenation activity and reduce the cracking products. However, the limitation of ZSM-5 includes presence of micropores, metal agglomeration and bulky aromatic product diffusion [24,32]. The presence of intracrystalline mesoporosity and dispersed extra framework Ga species facilitates aromatization and improves the BTX yield [33]. In the present case, GZSM-5 with micro and mesopores (as evidenced by BET in Table 2) was found to facilitate the easy accessibility of active site, while the presence of bimetals Ga and Zn facilitate the dehydrogenation and mild acidity (TPD) facilitate desorption of aromatics. The use of templating agent in synthesis of porous materials is being discouraged recently due to environmental concerns. Thus, in this work, the cracking activity of green template-free synthesized ZSM-5 zeolites were compared with template synthesized analog using the same bolus alpha precursor. 3.2.3 Effect of green Ga-Zn and conventional Ga-Zn on GZSM-5 and CZSM-5 The effect of bimetal Ga and Zn (2Ga0.5 Zn) derived from nitrate sources and Tribulus leaves (2GGa0.5 Zn) impregnated on GZSM-5 catalyst was studied. The results were compared with the conventional ZSM-5 catalyst (2Ga0.5Zn/CZSM-5) and is shown in Fig. 10 . The commercial ZSM-5 based 2Ga0.5Zn/CZSM-5 was observed to show high C3 conversion of 87.66 % along with C4 conversion of 100 %. However, the aromatic yield remains at 56.32 % with BTEX selectivity of 53.57 %. Notably, the selectivity of light hydrocarbons was significantly higher at 38.31 % (Fig. 10). Bimetal loading on GZSM-5 showed the highest aromatic yield with 76.00 % with BTEX selectivity to 44.38 %. It should be noted that GZSM-5 based catalyst showed high C9+ formation of 33.02 % higher than 2Ga0.5Zn/CZSM-5 (Fig. 10). On the other hand, 2GGa0.5Zn/GZSM-5 catalyst, where all the active species and support are derived from green source was able to convert C4 to 99.38 %, and C3 to 59.53 %. Interestingly, the aromatic yield and BTEX selectivity was similar to commercial formulation reaching at 53.96 % and 50.73 %, respectively. Most strikingly, the C9+ selectivity was lower at 3.22 %, while light hydrocarbons slightly increase to 28.08 % (Fig. 10). Metal oxide loading on ZSM-5 has been reported to reduce both weak and strong acid sites, thereby limiting hydrogen transfer reactions and alkane formation, ultimately favoring the production of aromatic compounds [34]. The synergistic combination of the intrinsic acid sites of ZSM-5 and the incorporation of modifiers such as Pt, Ga and Zn are known for its dehydrogenation properties—facilitates hydrocarbon conversion via alkene formation, oligomerization, and cyclization to aromatics [35]. In our study, Ga-modified ZSM-5 (GZSM-5) demonstrated an enhanced aromatization activity. It has been shown that alkane aromatization could be significantly improved with gallium/hierarchical zeolite consisting of interconnected secondary pore network between meso and micropores. The presence of micropores was reported to impart molecular diffusional strain, bulky gallium metal dispersibility and catalyst stability. For instance, the presence of mesopores significantly improved the BTX aromatics (∼56 %) compared to conventional microporous ZSM-5 (48.54 %). The presence of hierarchy was reported to be the critical factor in enhancing the mass transportation and extraframework Ga2O3 species migration [20].The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm of GZSM-5 revealed an increase in pore diameter, suggesting that Ga species are predominantly deposited on the pore walls rather than inside the micropores of ZSM-5 (Table 2). For comparison, AlMSU-F—with its large pore windows and high surface area—was capable of accommodating Ga species within its pores; however, this catalyst showed negligible aromatization activity. This highlights the critical role of Ga deposition at the external pore channels in promoting aromatization. 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 exhibits a significantly higher L/B ratio of 0.638, indicating an increased proportion of Lewis acid sites (Fig. 5 h). Furthermore, diffuse reflectance UV-Vis spectroscopy (DRS-UV-vis) revealed a broad absorption band corresponding to Ga clusters in GZSM-5 (Fig. 6b and c), indicating the presence of labile Ga species that interact moderately with the MFI framework. These extra-framework Ga3+ and Zn2+ species are responsible for the generation of Lewis acid sites and play a key role in enhancing the selectivity toward BTEX compounds (Fig. 10) [36]. Overall, this study shows that the aromatics along with heavier C9+ aromatics selectivity could be tuned by variation in the active Ga and Zn species derived from green sources on GZSM-5. The presence of abundant halloysite clay around the world promises cheap precursor starter for green based ZSM-5 synthesis, while Ga and Zn derived from nitrate and green precursor could be loaded to improve the selectivity of aromatics yield. 3.2.4 Time-on-Stream Stability testing of optimized catalyst The stability of the optimized 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 catalyst was evaluated under industrially relevant conditions (550 °C, 1 atm, GHSV = 1600 h⁻¹) over a 5 h time-on-stream (TOS) test, with results presented in Fig. 11 and Table S2. The catalyst exhibited moderate deactivation, evidenced by a 5 % decrease in C4 conversion (from 100 % to 95.31 %) and a 9.7 % reduction in C3 conversion (from 94.19 % to 84.99 %). Product distribution analysis revealed an 8.3 % decline in total aromatics yield (71.58 % to 65.65 %), driven primarily by a significant 38 % reduction in BTEX production, while heavier C9+ aromatics increased by 23 %, suggesting progressive catalyst coking and pore blockage. Post-reaction coke analysis confirmed approximately 5.4 wt.% coke deposition, consistent with the observed activity loss. While these results demonstrate reasonable initial stability, further studies are needed to optimize regeneration protocols (including oxidative and steam treatments), evaluate cycle stability (20+ cycles), to enhance long-term performance for industrial implementation. The observed deactivation patterns and planned mitigation strategies underscore the catalyst's potential while highlighting critical areas for improvement in durability and regenerability. 4 Conclusions In the pursuit of sustainable chemistry, the development of green catalysts represents a vital step toward reducing the environmental footprint of industrial and chemical processes. This study demonstrated the potential of sustainable Ga- and Ga-Zn-impregnated GZSM-5 catalysts for the aromatization of LPG, offering a promising route for cleaner hydrocarbon valorization. Among the three different catalysts, 2Ga/GZSM-5, 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5, and 2GGa0.5Zn/GZSM-5 were found to be active in the process. 2Ga/GZSM-5 catalyst exhibited labile nano Ga clusters and higher ratio of Lewis to Brønsted acid sites compared to commercial ZSM-5, achieving a high aromatic yield of 72.64 % with a BTEX yield of 61.10 %. The co-addition of Zn to Ga/GZSM-5 further enhanced the aromatic yield to 76.00 %, though it reduced the BTEX yield to 44.38 %. Additionally, the green bimetallic GaZn catalyst derived from plant extracts on GZSM-5 achieved an aromatic yield of 53.96 % with a BTEX yield of 50.73 %. The superior LPG aromatization performance was attributed to the hierarchical structure, intermediate acidity, and labile Ga clusters present in the green ZSM-5 catalyst. Moreover, scaling up the green synthesis approach using plant-derived precursors and accessing the long-term stability and recyclability of these catalysts under industrial conditions will be essential steps towards commercial viability. coredata.dc:description: This study explores the performance of bimetal Ga-Zn impregnated on green ZSM-5 and commercial ZSM-5 to convert liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) to aromatics. Initially, the activity of Ga-impregnated GZSM-5 (2Ga/GZSM-5) was evaluated and compared with various structured catalysts, halloysite clay nanotubes (2Ga/Hall), hierarchical MCM-41 (2Ga/HierMCM-41), mesocellular aluminosilicate foam (2Ga/AlMSU-F), and zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (2Ga/ZIF-8). The experiments were conducted using an LPG feed at a flow rate of 10 mL/min and 550 °C. Subsequently, the effect of Zn co-impregnation on 2Ga/GZSM-5, was investigated. Finally, a sustainable catalyst derived from green Ga-Zn metal nanoparticles synthesized from Tribulus leaves on GZSM-5 (2GGa0.5Zn/GZSM-5) was studied. The results revealed that 2Ga/GZSM-5 exhibited the highest aromatics yield of 72.64 % with a BTEX selectivity of 61.10 %. Among the bimetallic catalysts, 2Ga0.5Zn/GZSM-5 achieved the highest aromatics yield of 76.00 % with a BTEX selectivity of 44.38 %. This study highlights the potential of sustainable green metal nanoparticles combined with ZSM-5 for efficient LPG-to-aromatics conversion.
